channel.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
channel.description:
I was looking around online for jobs. I saw that Java developers wouldn't earn any less then a C++ programmer. Most jobs hardly require you to know multiple languages but maybe knowledge of SQL and other stuff instead.
C is a pretty hard language compared to Java. Would it be best to just stick with Java and go into a career as a Java programmer, I didn't see any differences in pay really.
Some people may want you to know Python or Ruby alongside Java (obvious reasons) so what do you guys think?

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:30, topic:546495”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665394.msg4448849#msg4448849 date=1410216298]

It’s most certainly not a waste of time

/thread

I don’t appreciate you being here. Sorry.

Okay I will take my leave after this reply. But really, he is right.
/duces

Look you barley even know Java. How long do you think it’ll take you to fully understand the language? Yeah transistioning to another language might be easier but it’s hella hard to do so.

Takes time. I have this idea that having 1 strong language would save a lot of time. I’ve been doing Java for around 4 years, I still suck. In a work environment you won’t be able to get people spoon feeding code when you get a problem. I’ve been learning pretty slow since I’ve started but from what I’ve heard it could take around 5 years to actually know a language (it’s just something I heard).

I know a few languages. I could write a couple of program’s sure. I still don’t know the language deep enough to not need google every 5 mins.

OP is really freaking “special”.
[/quote]Ya, OP is this community’s adopted child suffering from autism, even classic at least tries to control his ADD with pills.[/quote]
I’m pretty sure autism came as a perk for registering.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

The fact that you know other cool hipster languages should go on your resume. If you enjoy learning new languages, go ahead and learn them. You’ll understand programming at a more deeper level and get more involved. Just because most businesses use Java (maybe, for instance), doesn’t mean they wouldn’t like to see you involved in some other-language projects on Github.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Death Style:

do you even know one language or anything useful at all

I know enough to get what I need done.

Justin Bieber:

wtf, what jobs are you people doing where the programming language is the main difficulty? you can just google anything you’re stuck with

The types of jobs I’m aiming to find is based purely on programming.

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:23, topic:546495”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=665394.msg4448180#msg4448180 date=1409958970]
I still don’t know the language deep enough to not need google every 5 mins.
[/quote]
You don’t need to know every method of every class in every API ever made. What you do need to know how to do is put it all together into one place with a smooth flow. A very strong understanding of algorithms, design patterns, etc are all universal concepts that can be applied in almost any language.

If you are going to focus on Java, then you’ll definitely want to know the ins and outs of some portions of the stdlib, but you definitely don’t need to memorize it. Like knowing the main differences between an ArrayList vs LinkedList, or when to use HashMap vs TreeMap and their differences. You’ll also want to remember that Java’s Cloneable interface is a shallow copy, and you’ll want to know when/why a deep clone is needed.

Every language has its little quirks like this. Just make sure you figure out what they are[/quote]
It’s not about memorising it when you have the docs to reference. It’s the approach you take to solves problems. It differs a lot.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Ashi:

I still don’t know the language deep enough to not need google every 5 mins.

You don’t need to know every method of every class in every API ever made. What you do need to know how to do is put it all together into one place with a smooth flow. A very strong understanding of algorithms, design patterns, etc are all universal concepts that can be applied in almost any language.

If you are going to focus on Java, then you’ll definitely want to know the ins and outs of some portions of the stdlib, but you definitely don’t need to memorize it. Like knowing the main differences between an ArrayList vs LinkedList, or when to use HashMap vs TreeMap and their differences. You’ll also want to remember that Java’s Cloneable interface is a shallow copy, and you’ll want to know when/why a deep clone is needed.

Every language has its little quirks like this. Just make sure you figure out what they are

Read full topic

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:16, topic:546495”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=665394.msg4448080#msg4448080 date=1409931011]
Let’s just say that biggest C++ salaries are bigger than biggest any other language salaries.

But you’ll never be able to master the superior C++ language, so stick to Java. Why do you think it is so complex? To weed out dumbfudges like you.

I’m a God and getting paid like a God.
[/quote]you’re probably like 13, the only posts you make consist of elitist faggotry which even #mopar doesn’t do
tl;dr you’re retarded, move the fudge on son

C++ is a pretty complex language compared to Java.

I was thinking about C but wrote C++ haha. C is pretty difficult if you’re not a good programmer. A big mistake could easily mess up your PC.

Pointers are kinda hard to use too if you’re a rookie. Java is much more safe and easy to pickup. Better syntax too and other cool stuff.
[/quote]lol[/quote]
Deffo man no question about it!

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Whackatre:

“complex” wouldn’t be one of the words i would use to describe c, a relatively small and basic language. annoying to write/debug and easy to shoot yourself in the foot? perhaps.

Already changed it. I don’t like C that much

Read full topic
item.source: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?

item.title: Is it a waste of time learning different programming languages?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:9, topic:546495”][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=665394.msg4447969#msg4447969 date=1409859614]
imo it’d be a dumb move to just learn one language coz the industry changes too quickly and you can’t really predict which languages will come in useful. at least if you know a handful of languages you know you’re capable of learning others pretty easily.
[/quote]
This is true to some extent, though all I’ve ever really do is know a language at it’s basic form. I’ve never needed to code in something like VB or Pascal. I’ve never even found a proper use for learning LUA (even though some people still do). In fact I feel as if it was a waste of time because I don’t see myself or any job I go for using it.

C++ is a pretty complex language compared to Java.

I was thinking about C but wrote C++ haha. C is pretty difficult if you’re not a good programmer. A big mistake could easily mess up your PC.

Pointers are kinda hard to use too if you’re a rookie. Java is much more safe and easy to pickup. Better syntax too and other cool stuff.

wat

c might be more difficult to use (than java???) but it is most definitely not more complex than c++… quite literally – c++ is a superset of c.

No I wrote C++ by mistake. I’m talking about C ignore the fact I mentioned C++. The point I was making was even though C is more complex, a developers pay wouldn’t change. Just because the language may be harder to use doesn’t mean you’re going to earn more money.

Rust.

I’ve not seen anybody look for Rust developers yet. Rust is a good language though.

It’s most certainly not a waste of time

Learning something like Basic would be a waste of time :rolleyes: - The whole idea of going deep into a language puts me off because I don’t know if I’ll actually be using it.[/quote]

“complex” wouldn’t be one of the words i would use to describe c, a relatively small and basic language. annoying to write/debug and easy to shoot yourself in the foot? perhaps.

Read full topic

I’m a God and getting paid like a God.[/quote]
How much do you think the average salary for a C++ programmer is or yours? If it’s any more than £130,000,00 per year then I guess it’s worth going into otherwise just being a noob and doing Java (which is easier) would be so much better because you can get a decent pay from it.
